data.title: Recorded the hottest day since records are recorded, the average temperature on Earth for the first time 17 degrees Celsius

data.text:
It was never warmer on planet Earth than on Monday, July 3, according to data collected by meteorologists since the end of the 19th century.

The average temperature in the world that day exceeded 17 degrees Celsius, which has never been recorded before, say American researchers.

Scientists believe that these results were brought about by a combination of the natural El Niño climate phenomenon and continuous human-induced carbon dioxide emissions, which lead to greater warming.

The previous month was also the hottest June recorded globally.

Average maximum temperature in Serbia on July 3, 2023, it was 32,5 degrees Celsius.

How El Niño and La Niña change weather patterns

"Mankind's survival guide": UN report on climate change

Experts at the US National Weather Service Center said the global average temperature was 17,01 degrees Celsius on July 3, and the previous record was set in August 2016, when it was 16,92 degrees Celsius.

Since the beginning of this year, researchers have been concerned about the rise in land and sea temperatures.

Record spring heat in Spain and several Asian countries was accompanied by marine heat waves in areas where they are not common, such as the North Sea.

A long-lasting heat wave with temperatures above 35 degrees Celsius hit China this week, and unfavorable weather conditions were also recorded in the South of America.

The record seen on Monday is also the highest average temperature since weather conditions have been recorded by satellite, which began in 1979.

The El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) has three phases: warm, cold and neutral.

They represent the most powerful change in the climate system on Earth.

Climatological researcher Leon Simmons believes that the temperature data is "symbolically significant for our warming world.

"Now that the warmer phase of El Niño is starting, we can expect more daily, monthly and annual records over the next year and a half," he says.

Average temperatures last month were 1,46 degrees Celsius higher than those recorded across the planet during June between 1850 and 1900.

Great Britain had the warmest June, as well as Antarctica, where average temperatures of 8,7 degrees Celsius were read in the Ukrainian research base Vernadsky.

Scientists believe that new records will be set by the end of summer as El Niño gains strength.

"There is every chance that July will be the warmest month on record, and that means the warmest in the last 120.000 years," says Carsten Haustein of the University of Leipzig.

"While temperatures in the southern hemisphere of the Earth will drop slightly over the next few days, it looks like July and August will bring even warmer days as El Niño is now in full swing," adds the expert.
